Your letter:
Dear [MP Name], 

My name is Alana, and I am currently the primary carer for my 64-year-old mother who lives with me in our rural community of Kangaroo Island, postcode 5225. As our population ages, the responsibility of caring falls heavily on family members like me, navigating the complexities of health and aged care systems without adequate support.

The isolation of our location exacerbates this challenge, making access to services not only scarce but often completely unattainable without significant travel and expense. Each week, I find myself overwhelmed by the logistics of managing my mother's care, from scheduling medical appointments to understanding the maze of available aged care and home care services.

Moreover, the emotional toll and the strain on my personal and professional life are profound. Constantly juggling these responsibilities with no end in sight has left me both physically exhausted and mentally strained. 

It is for this reason that I am reaching out to urge your support for a national program like Violet’s, which aims to provide families like mine with vital guidance and support. Such a program would offer a lifeline, helping us to navigate the health and aged care systems more effectively, reducing the emotional burden, and allowing us to maintain our livelihoods while caring for our loved ones.

Please advocate for better caregiver support on a national level, ensuring that all Australians, regardless of where they live, have access to the resources they need during these challenging times.

Yours sincerely,
Alana

Dear [MP Name], 

My name is Gill Jewell, and I am currently navigating the profoundly challenging journey of preparing for the end-of-life care of my father. This period has spotlighted an array of difficulties, most notably the struggle to bring my family out of denial regarding the inevitability and the necessity of such planning.

Living in a rural suburb, the lack of accessible resources and services for elderly care compounds these challenges. The emotional toll and time required to manage these responsibilities alongside personal commitments are overwhelming. The journey is isolating, and the fear and uncertainty of not knowing if I am making the right decisions weigh heavily on me.

The support that would immensely change our lives includes guidance and assistance with end-of-life planning that respects the dignity of my father’s final years. This support would not only help us but also lighten the similar burdens on countless other Australian families facing these inevitable challenges.

I urge you to advocate for and support the implementation of Violet's national program. This initiative promises to provide essential support through practical guidance and emotional support that is crucial for caregivers nationwide, especially in rural and regional areas like ours.

By backing this program, you can help ensure that families can approach this sensitive phase with the respect and dignity it deserves. Your support could make a significant difference in the lives of countless Australians grappling with the complexities of aged care.

Yours faithfully,

Gill Jewell

Dear [MP Name], 

I write to you deeply concerned, both as a daughter and a member of the growing ‘Sandwich Generation’, managing the demanding role of caring for my 83-year-old father, Friedrich, from a distance. Despite him having a home care package, it falls short due to staffing shortages in our rural area of Berri, SA.

Each week, I dedicate numerous hours coordinating his care, which includes making phone calls to My Aged Care and his care coordinator, organising medical appointments, managing his finances, and ensuring he adheres to his medication. This commitment strains not only my professional life but also impacts my personal well-being, especially as I am anticipating the arrival of a grandchild.

The intermittent nature of the care available has left both my father and me in constant stress. This phase in our lives, which should be less worrisome and more fulfilling, is marred by uncertainty and exhaustion. The current system makes it challenging to access continuous and reliable support, a plight faced by many caregivers across the nation, particularly in rural and regional areas.

I urge for your active support in advocating for more comprehensive and effective national support frameworks. Improved navigation through health and aged care services, and a move towards consistent and adequate care provisions, would significantly alleviate the burdens faced by family caregivers.

Please consider bolstering support for caregivers by backing initiatives like Violet’s national program, addressing the unique challenges inherent in remote caregiving and ensuring our elderly can live with the dignity they deserve.

Warm regards,
Petra Ferrier

Dear [MP Name],

Dear [MP Name], 

My name is Lea-An, I’m writing not only on behalf of myself, but for countless Australians caught in the growing ‘Sandwich Generation’—those of us caring for ageing parents while trying to manage our own lives and responsibilities.

In the past 12 months, my life has been turned upside down. After my mother’s passing in September 2024, my 78-year-old father, Tom—who has dementia and diabetes—came to live with my partner and me in February 2024. 
Caring for him involves managing his meals, medication, daily routines, and ensuring he stays active. I’ve also returned to full-time work after receiving some support through his My Aged Care package (level 4), but the emotional and physical toll has been a lot.

My mum’s decline began after a fall in January 2024 while under my brother’s care. She was hospitalised and sadly could not return home due to the toxic and unsafe environment there. She entered a nursing home and passed away later that year from dementia and other health issues. Dad and I visited her as often as we could—despite living 50 minutes from the hospital and 40 minutes from the nursing home.

The situation at my parents’ home remains distressing. One of my brothers, who struggles with mental health issues linked to drug use, continues to live there despite being asked to leave multiple times. He contributes nothing financially and has remained in the home even after Dad moved out. I changed the locks, but he found a way back in. Police have been called numerous times due to his behaviour, and I’ve received very little support in trying to legally remove him. Thankfully, a social worker from the GEM team is now assisting us, which has been a blessing. They connected us with a community lawyer and supporting us through the SACAT process.

Emotionally, I’ve been running on empty. The hardest part of all this has been watching my dad slowly decline while feeling completely unprepared to manage the stages of dementia. I often don’t know if I'm  handling daily conversations correctly or how best to support him, and I live in constant fear that he’ll end up in a nursing home—just like my mum did—something I’m desperate to avoid. 

I want him to live his remaining years in a place where he feels safe, respected, and surrounded by love with family & his dog.
One of the most positive and uplifting supports in our lives right now is the ECH Wellness site, which we affectionately call his “daycare.” Currently, he only attends once a week (Due to the cost $200 a day this isn't including the cost of a carer picking him up/ dropping him off and their time - this comes out of his level 4 package), 

It would make such a difference to his wellbeing if he could attend more often—ideally weekdays. At ECH, he’s mentally and physically engaged through music, exercise, and woodwork. It’s a space where he connects socially, which is so important for those living with dementia.
This kind of arrangement—living at home with family while attending the Wellness site for daily enrichment—would allow Dad to live a longer, happier, and more fulfilled life. It would also provide my partner and me with crucial respite and peace of mind, knowing he’s supported both emotionally and socially.

That’s why I’m urging you to advocate for and support funding for Violet’s national program. It would provide compassionate, practical guidance to carers like myself who are struggling to understand dementia, make informed care decisions, and maintain our own emotional wellbeing. As our population ages, programs like Violet and increased access to community-based day care options are vital—not only for the elderly but also for the family members who are their lifelines.
Thank you for taking the time to consider my story and the pressing need for stronger, more accessible aged care support.
Kind regards,
Lea-Ann

As a daughter and niece tasked with the care of my 94-year-old mother, 81-year-old aunt and 87-year-old uncle, I am deep in the challenges faced by many Australians in their roles as family caregivers. The weight of increased care needs and frequent medical visits has necessitated a reduction in my working hours, reshaping my life significantly.

The hours dedicated to navigating healthcare services, organising aged-care support, and ensuring my loved ones’ well-being are considerable. I find myself constantly torn between my responsibilities as a caregiver, maintaining a professional career, and my own personal needs. This challenge is amplified by the complex and sometimes inaccessible array of services available, making an already tough situation more arduous.

I believe that a structured assistance programme could transform my situation and the lives of countless others in similar circumstances. Support programs that help caregivers navigate health, aged care, and home care services, as well as assist in planning for the last stages of life, would be of immense benefit. Such provisions would not only aid in practical terms but also provide emotional support and guidance on having critical conversations about the future.

Therefore, I urge you to advocate for and support the funding of a national caregiver program such as Violet's. This initiative would help alleviate the pressures and challenges faced by the 'Sandwich Generation' as we care for our ageing loved ones whilst juggling other life responsibilities. Your support could significantly influence our ability to care compassionately and effectively.

Thank you for considering this vital issue affecting many Australian families.

Warm regards,

Lisa Davies

Dear [MP Name], 

My name is Vicki Rutherford from Blacktown, NSW, postcode 2148. My mother, Jean, who is 95 years old, now largely depends on me for her care. Over the past few years, my role has transitioned from being her daughter to being her primary caregiver. This change has been profound and challenging.  I generally was working 4 days a week as well.

My mother currently requires care in a hospital setting that is both overcrowded and understaffed, making it necessary for me to advocate for her and be there overnight & during the day as she has a mild to moderate dementia and was high functioning at home until her fall.  

I was strongly encouraged to not bring her to hospital as she is better at home & that goes without saying.  At home Mum became weaker each day 
over the course of the week with the pain increasing & her ability to walk declining.  

I'm at the hospital to ensure she receives the basic necessities such as food, and to encourage her proper nutrition.  Also to ensure her medication is considered carefully due to her dementia. The emotional and physical toll this takes on me is significant, impacting my own wellbeing.  I choose not to work during this phase as a result of the staffing & over-crowding issues.  

One of the toughest parts of this journey is the complexity of navigating health and aged care services. A streamlined system or support navigating these services would immensely relieve some of the pressures we face.

It is, therefore, my humble request that you advocate for better support structures for caregivers through initiatives like Violet's national program that offers crucial guidance and practical help in managing aged care. Support for caregivers, especially in ensuring adequate staffing in healthcare facilities, is crucial not just for the wellbeing of our elderly but also for those who care for them. Your support in advocating for these changes will make a meaningful difference to many Australian families.

Warm regards,
Vicki Rutherford

Over the years, my parents' health has declined significantly, requiring more of my attention and presence. Additionally, as my sons transition into adulthood, the administrative demands from services like NDIS, Centrelink, and others have significantly increased. This continual balancing act greatly impacts my emotional wellbeing and strains my capacity to manage other life responsibilities.

One of the most formidable hurdles is the immense bureaucracy involved in accessing support services. The complexity of systems and frequent technical issues add unnecessary stress and often delay the needed support, making a difficult job even harder.

The support that would truly make a difference for my family and me would include simplified access to services and a support system designed to understand and adapt to the challenges families like mine face, especially in managing family dynamics during high-stress situations.

I urge you to consider advocating for better support systems for caregivers across Australia. As our population ages, many more will find themselves in similar situations. Supporting a national program like Violet’s could provide essential guidance and respite for countless families, easing the emotional and administrative burdens we face daily.

Thank you for taking the time to consider this significant issue.

Yours sincerely,

Sarah Cass

Dear [MP Name], 

I am writing to you today as a daughter, a mother, and a part of the 'Sandwich Generation' caring for both my young son and my elderly mother, Bonnie, who is 84 years old and currently living with advanced dementia. As her sole caregiver, the necessities of managing her financial affairs and making all decisions on her behalf with her nursing home have entirely fallen on my shoulders.

The complexities entailed in securing power of attorney, combined with the challenge of making critical life decisions without prior discussions with my mother, who can no longer communicate her wishes, have significantly intensified the emotional and logistical burdens of my everyday life. The journey has been isolating and daunting, shedding light on the stark needs facing caregivers like myself across Australia, particularly those managing the extremes of life—from childcare to eldercare.

Given these pressing circumstances, it is clear that caregivers nationwide would benefit immensely from structured support. We need accessible programs that provide guidance for having essential conversations, navigating health, aged care, and home care services, and effectively planning for life’s final stages.

I urge you to advocate for the introduction and funding of Violet’s national program, which promises to offer such support. This initiative would not only aid in improving the quality of life for our elderly but also immensely support caregivers who play a critical role in their lives.

The support from such programs could truly make a significant difference by easing the load on our shoulders and ensuring better care for our loved ones. 

Thank you for considering this significant matter.

Warm regards,

Kathryn Collins

Dear [MP Name], 

My name is Carol Macfarlane, and I am reaching out to share the considerable challenges I face as a primary carer for my father, Raymond Trimble, who is 86. Having lived with me for 16 years, his deteriorating health from vascular dementia and mobility issues necessitated his move to an aged care facility two years ago. This transition heightened his needs and mine, fundamentally altering our lives.

As Raymond's sole guardian and the only family member involved in his care, my responsibilities include making all medical decisions and managing frequent, distressing calls from him and the care staff. This has had a profound impact on my well-being, leading to significant health problems such as high blood pressure, depression, and migraines with aura that severely limit my functional capability.

The emotional and financial toll has been immense. Having to leave full-time work, our family income dropped drastically, and my husband, at 75, has had to continue working with no prospect of retiring. We are financially and emotionally stretched, trying to support not just my father but also our daughter who struggles with mental illness.

The hardest aspect is witnessing my father's profound suffering, knowing his life is drawing to a close in such challenging circumstances. This experience underscores the urgent need for a robust support system for carers like myself, especially in managing the complex aged care environment and ensuring better-trained facility staff.

I urge you to advocate for increased support and resources for family carers through policies that address both the economic and emotional burdens we carry. Support for initiatives like Violet’s national program could provide critical guidance and relief to countless Australians in similar situations.

Yours sincerely,

Carol Macfarlane
Frenchs Forest, NSW, 2086

Yours sincerely,

Jae

I urge your strong advocacy for increased funds and support towards national programs designed to assist caregivers, including strong advocacy to maintain flexible working conditions. I have 16 years of working life left until retirement age, but am highly concerned that Peter Duttons push to stop working from home arrangements for public servants like myself will mean that I would be unable to support my parents and continue to work. I am currently able to work full time and accompany my parents and my aunt to appointments, as there is less travel time involved than there would be if i were in the office full time. His final years were unfortunately complicated not only by his health challenges but also by significant administrative struggles with NDIS, impacting his dignity and our family's well-being.

The emotional toll of fighting for these basic rights, coupled with caregiving, was overwhelming. This experience illustrates a gaping need for comprehensive support for caregivers, especially as it pertains to planning and managing the last stages of life including how to cover funeral costs with significant grief and financial strain already impacting the family.

The introduction of a national program that aids in planning and provides tangible assistance for caregivers could transform many lives, ensuring dignity and support in the final stages of life and beyond.

Support that could make a difference to me and countless others in similar situations includes accessible guidance in navigating health and aged care systems, and counselling to help manage the complex family dynamics that emerge in these settings, especially under stress.

I implore you to advocate for Violet’s national program, which promises practical support and resources for people like me, caught in the web of caregiving across generations. Each week, my responsibilities vary widely from managing simple medical appointments to implementing complex care plans, consuming several hours that often conflict with the needs of my own dependent children.

For far too many Australians, particularly in the 'Sandwich Generation', this dual responsibility results in an agonising choice between caring for ageing parents and fulfilling commitments to our children and careers. This constant juggling act has forced me to utilise my annual leave to address my father's medical needs – a sacrifice that impacts both my financial stability and emotional wellbeing.

The difficulties of coordinating care, which fluctuate dramatically, underscore the urgent need for structured support systems that can assist families like mine to navigate the harrowing journey through aged care and family dynamics. Specifically, programs that assist with important conversations about advanced care planning, alongside navigating the labyrinth of health, aged and home care services, would be invaluable.

Thus, I urge you to advocate for better support at a national level for caregivers across Australia through funding and policies, such as those proposed in Violet’s national program. This initiative not only promises vital educational resources and psychological support but also offers guidance in managing the increasingly complex aspects of aged care.

Your commitment to this cause can significantly improve the lives of millions of Australians facing similar struggles, affording them the dignity and support they desperately need in their dual caregiving roles.

Warm regards,

Anne Lifschitz

In recent years, I have witnessed her condition deteriorate, demanding an increase in the time and energy I dedicate daily to ensure her wellbeing. Despite my commitments, I am there several hours each day, managing her health monitoring, finances, and household needs.

Lesley's evolving symptoms are met with consistent challenges, including her reluctance and frequent disagreement due to her condition—a scenario that often escalates family tensions. This dynamic not only strains my emotional resilience but significantly impacts the time I can devote to my own life and responsibilities. The strain of balancing these commitments is a reality for many across our nation, prominently among individuals in rural and remote areas like ours in suburb 4211, where resources and support services are limited.

Given these conditions, I strongly advocate for your support of Violet’s national program. This initiative promises to provide essential guidance, support in managing family dynamics during such critical times, and practical assistance in navigating aged care services. For caregivers like myself, this support would be invaluable, lightening our emotional load and enabling us to provide better care for our loved ones.

It is urgent we acknowledge and act on the necessities of the 'Sandwich Generation,' who tirelessly care for their aging parents while managing their own lives. Please, let us enhance our support structures and ensure no caregiver has to endure this journey unsupported.

Thank you for considering this vital matter.

Warm regards,

Amanda Sawyers-White
